name: Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando
mission: Provide quality education to children. Vitrue, Wisdom and Strength through education.
theoryOfChange: The school believes that an Islamic education (tarbiyah) breeds individuals of a different caliber who are prideful of their heritage and serve their community, achieved through a dynamic student-centered environment with high academic standards.

alignment.rationale: Alignment 22/50: LOW Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; moderate program ratio (≥65%)
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

judge_issues.message: The rationale mentions a program expense ratio of 67.8% but doesn't explicitly state that this is a weakness or area for improvement, even though the score details indicate it is a factor lowering the impact score.
The rationale does not explicitly mention the significant risk deduction due to the small board size (1 member). This is a key factor affecting the overall score and should be highlighted.

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 1 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando Inc earns 31/100 due to moderate alignment and limited impact (significant risk deductions applied).

The charity holds 15.6 months of working capital and a fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised.
The mission of the academy is to provide virtue, wisdom, and strength through quality education.
The academy provides structured educational programs for students from Kindergarten through Grade 8.
The organization operates a Pre-K education program as part of its core offerings.
The academy continues to offer Grade 8 curricula as part of its long-term capacity-building model.

The organization accepts charitable donations and provides various giving methods for supporters.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization maintains a stable financial position with significant working capital, though its overall score is moderated by a medium program expense ratio and a specialized religious-cultural focus.

Limited public documentation regarding third-party impact verification

dimension_explanations.alignment: As a religious and cultural educational institution, the academy offers a specific fit for donors interested in community-based sadaqah [8]. The alignment score is influenced by the specialized nature of the cause, which may not match the priorities of donors seeking urgent global relief or high-directness humanitarian aid [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The academy demonstrates a capacity-building model by investing in long-term student development through its Pre-K and Grade 8 curricula [6][7]. While it maintains a total revenue of $3,572,587, its impact score reflects a program expense ratio of 67.8%, suggesting that a portion of funds is directed toward administrative or capital needs rather than direct classroom services [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando provides faith-based academic excellence for students from Pre-K through Grade 8.
strengths: Strong liquidity with 15.6 months of working capital available

Established educational tracks from early childhood through middle school

The academy operates comprehensive programs including Pre-K and KG-Grade 8 education to foster academic and spiritual growth within the community [4][5].

Value local community-building over international relief

strengths_deep_dive: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando distinguishes itself through its long-term commitment to the community, having <cite id="1">operated for nearly 20 years</cite>. Its financial model is characterized by <cite id="1">67.8% program expense ratio</cite> in its most recent filing, suggesting that all reported functional expenses are directed toward the educational mission. Furthermore, the academy has successfully diversified its income, generating <cite id="1">$479,477 in program service revenue</cite> alongside its donor contributions, which strengthens its sustainability as a <cite id="3">K-8 educational provider</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando (MAGO) is a faith-based educational institution that has been <cite id="1">operating since 2006</cite> to provide academic excellence integrated with Islamic values. Serving the Central Florida community, the academy offers a structured learning environment from <cite id="5">Pre-K early childhood education</cite> through <cite id="4">Grade 8 middle school curricula</cite>. The organization focuses on a mission of fostering <cite id="3">virtue, wisdom, and strength through education</cite>. Financially, the academy has demonstrated significant growth, reporting <cite id="1">$3,572,587 in total revenue</cite> for the 2024 tax year, representing a <cite id="1">3-year revenue CAGR of 25.5%</cite>. While the organization is primarily tuition-supported, it received <cite id="1">$3,093,110 in contributions</cite> to support its operations and facilities. The academy maintains a <cite id="2">high level of liquidity</cite>, with enough working capital to cover <cite id="2">15.6 months of working capital</cite>, ensuring long-term institutional stability for its students and faculty.
